item.title: Dozens killed in Russian missile strike on Ukrainian city of Poltava
item.dc:creator: Siobhán O'Grady, Jennifer Hassan
item.description: Two missiles targeted an educational institution and a nearby hospital, leaving many people trapped under rubble, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said.

item.title: Anger over Oasis ticket prices sparks U.K. review of dynamic pricing
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jeong, Julian Mark
item.description: Delight at the Oasis reunion turned to outrage when fans found the pricing model meant some tickets had more than doubled in price while they queued online.

item.title: Harry Potter fans boo as ‘miserable muggles’ nix annual King’s Cross event
item.dc:creator: Adela Suliman
item.description: The train station in London canceled its annual “Back to Hogwarts” tradition, a public announcement that the Hogwarts Express was ready to depart.

item.title: U.K. defends decision to restrict arms to Israel; Netanyahu calls it shameful
item.dc:creator: Victoria Bisset, Loveday Morris
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the decision to halt 30 of 250 arms export licenses was “shameful,” while Amnesty International called it insufficient.

item.title: More than 100 killed in failed Congo jail break at overcrowded prison
item.dc:creator: Rachel Chason, Rael Ombuor
item.description: The prison in the Congolese capital, Kinshasa, was notorious for its overcrowding, with conditions described by Amnesty International as “appalling.”

item.title: How China extended its repression into an American city
item.dc:creator: Shibani Mahtani, Meg Kelly, Cate Brown, Cate Cadell, Ellen Nakashima, Chris Dehghanpoor
item.description: The events in San Francisco illustrate how the Chinese Communist Party is willing to target people exercising their First Amendment rights in an American city

item.title: We investigated how China silenced its critics in an American city
item.dc:creator: Washington Post staff
item.description: The events in San Francisco illustrate how the Chinese Communist Party is willing to target U.S. citizens and residents exercising their First Amendment rights.

item.title: Two U.S. Marines attacked in Turkey by nationalist youth group
item.dc:creator: Frances Vinall
item.description: Police detained 15 people after the assault. Video shows assailants shouting “Yankee go home” and covering one Marine’s head in what looked like a white sack.

item.title: Turkey’s stray dogs, once ‘masters of the road,’ face new peril
item.dc:creator: Beril Eski
item.description: A new law requires municipalities to round up stray dogs and euthanize the ones that are feral. It has drawn outrage in a country where committed citizens have long cared for street animals.

item.title: Protests continue in Israel as Netanyahu faces outcry over hostage strategy
item.dc:creator: Steve Hendrix, Shira Rubin
item.description: After Hamas killed six hostages, Israel erupted in protests over Netanyahu’s policy of using the military rather than negotiations to recover the captives.

item.title: Maduro’s government orders arrest of candidate who U.S. says won more votes
item.dc:creator: Samantha Schmidt
item.description: Venezuela’s public prosecutor’s office accused opposition candidate Edmundo González of “usurpation” and instigating disobedience, among other charges.

item.title: U.K. suspends some arms sales to Israel after government review
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Hassan
item.description: The move marks a shift for the United Kingdom and came as part of the new Labour government’s review of Israel’s compliance with international humanitarian law.

item.title: Putin travels to Mongolia, defying international court arrest order
item.dc:creator: Robyn Dixon
item.description: Signatories to the Rome Statute are expected to carry out its arrest warrants, but Mongolia has close ties to Russia.

item.title: Hvaldimir, beloved beluga whale and alleged Russian spy, found dead
item.dc:creator: Leo Sands
item.description: The beluga whale was found in Norway wearing a St. Petersburg-marked harness, prompting speculation that he was a Russian intelligence asset.

item.title: German leader urges parties to boycott far right after its election wins
item.dc:creator: Kate Brady
item.description: The far-right AfD came in first in state elections in Thuringia and a close second in Saxony, so building a coalition government without it will be difficult.

item.title: A nature lover, a young father: Who were the 6 hostages found dead in Gaza?
item.dc:creator: Niha Masih, Rachel Pannett
item.description: Israel is mourning six slain hostages who were abducted by Hamas on Oct. 7. The government estimates 64 hostages remain alive in Gaza.

item.title: India’s growing reliance on China poses challenge for U.S. trade strategy
item.dc:creator: Karishma Mehrotra
item.description: The United States is looking to Indian manufacturing as a way to reduce commercial ties with Chinese factories and avoid supply disruptions due to tensions.

item.title: ‘Dark’ tanker crash exposes dangers of China’s thirst for cheap oil
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Tan, Pei-Lin Wu, Júlia Ledur
item.description: Dark ships — vessels that deliberately hide their locations — delivering oil to China are posing major safety threats and alarming global shipping groups.

item.title: American family’s quest to save son held captive in Gaza ends in heartbreak
item.dc:creator: Joanna Slater, Greg Jaffe
item.description: The parents of Hersh Goldberg-Polin, a dual Israeli and American citizen, had become public faces of the ordeal of the hostages taken by Hamas. Other American families of hostages fear time is running out for their loved ones.

item.title: Protests escalate in Israel after 6 hostages’ bodies are recovered in Gaza
item.dc:creator: Shira Rubin, Niha Masih, Joanna Slater, Lior Soroka
item.description: Hersh Goldberg-Polin, an Israeli American, and five others Hamas took hostage on Oct. 7 were killed “shortly before” being found, the Israel Defense Forces said.

item.title: Mass polio vaccinations in Gaza amid limited pause in fighting, U.N. says
item.dc:creator: Kareem Fahim, Leo Sands, Niha Masih
item.description: Israel permitted a “humanitarian corridor” for mass polio vaccinations in designated areas of Gaza, after the disease was detected there for the first time in 25 years.

item.title: Far right set to win in a German state for the first time since WWII
item.dc:creator: Kate Brady, Anthony Faiola
item.description: Deemed an extremist organization by domestic intelligence in three German states, the AfD has overcome deep-seated taboos over nationalist politics in Germany.

item.title: How many hostages are still in Gaza since Hamas attack on Israel? What to know.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Bisset, Sammy Westfall, Helier Cheung
item.description: Israel estimates some 117 hostages held by Hamas have been released or freed; 64 are believed still to be alive in Gaza. Here’s what we know.

item.title: Ukraine launches massive drone attack on Russian energy infrastructure
item.dc:creator: Siobhán O'Grady
item.description: Russia said it downed 158 drones in what appeared to be one of the largest Ukrainian drone attacks yet. Fires broke out at energy facilities, including in Moscow.
